Adopting Application Security Guidelines

Borland recommends that your company follow the application security guidelines outlined below until you become familiar with its method of handling user and group permissions.

From the Server

When creating users and groups with the User Manager dialog:

  • Do not change the privileges for the All Users, Administrators, System Managers, and Security Administrators groups.

  • Do not create additional groups under the Administrators group.

  • Create the groups that you need under the All Users group or under other groups that have already been placed under the All Users group.

  • Create new users as members of the All Users group.

  • Make sure that at least two users are Administrators, in case one Administrator is locked out for some reason. By default, members of the Administrators group have full privileges (the rights to do anything required in the application or the server.

  • Remember that access rights may be overridden by settings on the Access Rights dialog for System Policy. See Using/Ignoring Object Ownership and Group Privileges.

From the Application

When setting access rights:

  • Grant access right. Although you can deny access rights, this is not recommended. If you must deny certain access rights:

    • Never allow any node on an Access Rights dialog to have only deny rights records.

    • Always ensure that deny rights records on a node precede the grant rights records for that node.

    • Be aware that the Windows client and the Cross-Platform client interpret this item differently. Unchecked items are interpreted as valid in the Windows client, while checked items are interpreted as valid in the Cross-Platform client.

  • Set access rights at the highest possible level that works for your team. The application checks for access rights from the lowest level (the Item level) to the highest level (the Project level).

  • Set access rights at the Project level first. These rights should be set for every group (except the All Users group) for every node. The nodes are Project, View, Promotion State, Child Folders, File, Change Request, Requirement, Task, and Topic. The most important nodes to set at this level are the Project and View nodes. The Project node is the only place where project access rights can be set, while the View node controls access to all views. Initially, newly created views start out with only the view access rights set here.

  • Set access rights at the View level next. These rights should be set for every user and/or group that needs access at this level for every node. The nodes are View, Promotion State, Child Folders, File, Change Request, Requirement, Task, and Topic.

  • Grant access rights at the Folder level only if necessary. These settings accompany the folder when it is moved to or shared with a new view, although they change when it branches. Avoid setting access rights on root folders, as these rights can conflict with rights set at the project or view levels.

  • Avoid setting access rights on items. These settings accompany the item when it is moved to or shared with a new view, although they change when it branches.

  • Remember that if you set access rights for any user or group for a specific node in an Access Rights dialog, all users and/or groups who are not included are denied all access rights for that node. In general, if you set access rights for any node, be sure to set the access rights for all users and/or groups that may need to access the objects affected by that node.
